Electric flux & field are 2 different entities. Flux is scalar qty. measured by its density while field is a vector qty. shown by line with arrow. A charge has flux but not field around it.  Electric field is a force field which appears only when electric fluxes of one charge interacts with flux of other charge. Both,  flux density & electric field strength follow inverse sq. law. Change in flux density and motion of flux produce all forces and motions. Flux density b/w like charges increases which produces repulsive force while flux density b/w opposite decreases which produces attractive force.

For the reply section, let me clear this out. Other countries besides the USA are making students learning college level work in high school, so Gen z and millennials learn more things than Gen x and baby boomers.   In the USA, however, it is optional for students to learn college level stuffs in high school (I.e. AP courses, Cambridge, and dual enrollment), so they could pay less and graduate sooner.  And that’s why you get a bachelor’s degree in other counties for 2 years while in the USA, it’s 4 years (unless you took ap and Cambridge).  Edit: I need to change my grammar mistakes lol 😂

The divergence theorem requires a differentiable vector field but electric field from Coulomb's law diverges at the origin. Consequently, Gauss's flux theorem is not applicable to the divergence of the electric field. https://sites.google.com/view/physics-news/home/updates
